unit: Unit 8 | Inference for Categorical Data: Chi-Square
title: Math Program: Chi Squared Goodness of Fit
question_text: Suppose a high school principal wishes to determine if students in her after-school math program perform better than those not in the program. The principal randomly selected $115\text{ students}$ for an after-school study session that runs $3\text{ days per week}$ for $1\text{ hour}$ each day, focusing solely on math. The grade distribution of these students’ math grades is compared to the historical grade distribution of students’ math grades at this high school. The data is below: A B C D F After-School Program (Counts) 28 38 36 9 4 Historical Grade Distribution (%) 18% 32% 25% 20% 5% What conclusion can be drawn from the data when performing a chi-squared goodness of fit test?

choices.text: Strong evidence exists that the program causes higher math grades.
There is weak evidence that higher grades are attributed to the program.
No relationship exists between the program and higher grades.
Strong evidence exists that students in the program have a different grade distribution than everyone else does.
We failed to find evidence that the distribution of grades of students in the program is any different than everybody else.
